prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Reglet of Rumbledroom Quill

In nibbled night when reglets glare  
and furniture with fruzzle stares,  
the smudgefloor shivers under glowm—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.  

Besprank the jointage, flort the hinge,  
unspume the swivel’s crank-winged fringe;  
portcullis clinks, the spirals croon—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.  

Beware the wraffle, snattle, snear,  
that squirms through grooves of inkmosfear;  
its typish tongue will plume your doom—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.  

With quilster keen and blotcloth bent,  
inkbraced he croons through parchment vent;  
brass folios clatter, papyrs flail—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.  

He flipflunks past the deskbeast’s maw  
where drawers exhale a lineny yaw;  
he whifftacks on through spluttery gloom—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.  

Tweedle! clapstick! blotspatter! clang!—  
the reglet lunges with rangtang fang!  
furniture bristles, ink gushes wide—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.

He crimps its tail, he corkscrews nibs,  
resealing oozage with paperclip jibs;  
the smudgefloor settles into room—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.  

Back past the crank-winged fringe he glides,  
through slot of dusk where pages glide;  
“Hast tame the terror?” whispers gloam—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.  

In nibbled night when reglets glare  
and furniture with fruzzle stares,  
the smudgefloor shivers under glowm—  
prithee hush the quibblet’s hloom.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Bluedcrew’s Ticktockery

Beware the bluedcrew, blintering bright,  
It whirrs within the whickering night;  
Its screwish heart, a cobalt sting,  
Spins time itself on whirliging wing.  

He took the clickspanner, keen and small,  
The oil-drop phial, the springlet thrall;  
He hushed the ticktocks, one by one,  
Till silence clenched like a clapperclung sun.  

One tick!—the bluedcrew flashed in view,  
Its facets flared a feverish blue;  
It snarled in clicks, it snapped in clacks,  
It gnashed the gears with gimcrack hacks.  

He twizzled the micro-mighty key,  
He pressed the pawl of destiny;  
With twistle-torque and fingertip,  
He stilled the screw’s insidious slip.  

Back through the caseback, gleam and glide,  
He bore the tamed blue heart inside;  
“O frabjous day! Callooh! Calay!”  
He chortled in his ticktock way.  

Beware the bluedcrew, blintering bright,  
It whirrs within the whickering night;  
Yet if you meet its cobalt sting,  
Recall the twist that clipped its wing.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration Over Stubble  

I.  
When stubble whispers brown and brittle,  
and dusk begins to clink,  
a skurling skraw of star-winged skrittles  
goes glibbering on the brink.  

II.  
“Beware the Skirrwidge, clacklet, cloon!”  
the scarecrow gribbles low;  
“Sharpen your scythes, unbung the moon,  
and crank the lantern’s glow!”  

III.  
He took his whiffling whindleblade,  
his coat of clattered straw,  
and waited where the wind had laid  
a frost of tin and thaw.  

IV.  
One hush—then all the sky unseamed;  
the Skirrwidge swooped in spangles,  
a storm of ink with thistledreams,  
a rattle-bang of bangles.  

V.  
One! Two! A swish, a swank, a swipe!  
He sliced the swirling gloom;  
the stubble sang a silver stripe—  
the night let out a boom.  

VI.  
“Come clutch your clods, ye clacking host,  
the Skirrwidge is unclawed!”  
He hoisted high the rust-red ghost  
and twirled it, proud and awed.  

VII.  
When stubble whispers brown and brittle,  
and dusk begins to clink,  
a hush of wings in brittle skrittles  
remembers, soft, the brink.
label: high
